author: Raph

text: David Wise pushed the synths on the SNES further than almost anyone. He said in an interview that when Rare gave him the green light to be the composer for this game, he made it his mission to push the music on the Super Nintendo further than it had ever gone before. I think he succeeded. He has continued to make music for games over the years, but his work on the first two Donkey Kong Country games was truly lightning in a bottle. The perfect games with the perfect composer.
author: Shadoninja

text: Brambles in the sky. It's great, imaginative imagery that gave the 90s a certain trippy feel. Even in Super Mario 64 with that one underwater boxed room with windows, again floating in the sky and the Dire, Dire Docks theme. I can't really explain the euphoric feel you get from these tracks and imagery, but whatever it is, it needs to exist more in games today. And to be honest, the one game to look out for is Cyberpunk 2077. Maybe we'll experience something unforgettable again soon.

text: Man I remember playing this game when I was 7. Sometimes I would go to my grandmas house and play this game. She had all 3 games but I played this one the most. I beat this game a few years ago when I was 10 I believe I'm 13 now. This just reminds me when I was at my grandmas house staying the night and telling her I beat a level I was stuck on. Man I won't forget when me and my brother played this game too, now he works all the time and is very stressed. And when my mom and dad didn't fight all the time. This song brings back good memories when my family didn't go to shit, but makes me sad because I wish I could go back to those times and spend more time with my friends and family. I always listen to this when I'm sad or stressed or doing homework. If only it could be like the past again.

text:
¬°Cierto! 
Dan ganas de llorar. 
Recuerdate: t√∫, un ni√±o peque√±o, cuya mayor preocupaci√≥n era tener la nueva consola. El mundo no es Rosa, pero recuerda, no ten√≠as otro problema m√°s que pasar ese nivel. Tu padre te ayudaba y os echabais unas risas, pero no lo lograbais. 
Y pasan los a√±os... 
Te haces una persona mayor, esa inocencia tan dulce que caracteriza a los ni√±os, desaparece de tu interior. 
Intentas volver a ser como antes pero no puedes. Te das cuenta de que va a ser imposible disfrutar de tal forma la vida. Pero eres un adulto, tienes preocupaciones y problemas. 
Lo √∫nico que nos queda es ese sentimiento, con el que m√°s de uno de nosotros tenemos una relaci√≥n de amor-odio, la nostalgia.
Para todos los ni√±os, incluidos nosotros mismos de peque√±os. Que dec√≠amos que quer√≠amos ser adultos para poder conducir y no ir a la escuela. Pues miremonos, en que nos hemos convertido. 
Ya nada ser√° como antes, el tiempo sigue avanzando a una velocidad vertiginosa, y con el; se lleva a nuestros seres queridos. 
As√≠ que, vida solo hay una, y hay que disfrutar el momento. 
Porque si no lo hiciste, tu tren ya paso. No lo podr√°s volver a hacer. 

Y si, ya lo se. 
Unas l√°grimas recorren tus mejillas, pero √°nimo, la vida sigue. 
Disfruta del momento, vamos ¬°Hazlo!
Disfruta la canci√≥n y no te pares a pensar en otras cosas. 

Gracias.

text:
For the first 10 years of my life I didn't really care for music or paid much attention to it. But then I played this level and heard this song. I paused the game for about an hour and just letting it loop.

As I type this my eyes begin water...this song has actually changed my life to the point of turning me into the music addict I am today. 

Every month or two I either discover a new artist or get a new album from an artist I already favour. I can't even guess the amount of songs, artists, and genres I even like.

Not to mention I've been playing guitar for 15 years now and have also written countless of songs.

I owe it all to David Wise for composing Stickerbrush Symphony

text: When i close my eyes to this song.. i remember.. it‚Äôs a sunny afternoon in our old house. My mom and i are playing this game in my parents bedroom.. The sound of birds chirping outside.. The smell of the forest and our newly cut lawn.. The smell and sound of the hakkeboef my dad is making for dinner (hakkeboef is a danish thing ;)) Not a care in the world.. just me. My family. My game. The only ‚Äúcare‚Äù was not wanting to go to school the next day, or going early to bed. The world feelt more simple.. more quiet.. Funny how fast time moves sometimes.. Well just a little memory i wanted to share :) never forget your childhood.

text:
If I had to make a top ten list of best video game music of all time, in my opinion, it would go as follows:

10) Castle theme - Super Mario World

9) Boss Battle - Sonic the Hedgehog 2

8) Castle Theme - Super Mario RPG

7) Simple and Clean - Kingdom Hearts

6)  Move Forward fearlessly - Dragon Ball Z: Budokai 1

5) Opening Sequence theme - Super Smash Bros Brawl

4) Autumn plains - Spyro 2: Ripto's Rage!

3) Safe Room - Resident Evil 1

2) Temple of light theme - Fable

1) Stickerbrush Symphony - Donkey Kong Country 2

text: Hey everyone, I‚Äôm back for year 2 of my life update. My girlfriend and I broke up after 5 years. I always played this song around her and she would hum it. It was painful to come back here till now. I really still miss her and hopefully we may be able to work on rebuilding again. Hope you all have been well.

text: Hey all, I‚Äôm back with a quick not a year update. Yeah, so spoke with my ex last night and she said she met this new guy and has feelings for him. I spent all week doing the no contact rule to hope she would come back and miss me but clearly it didn‚Äôt work out like I wanted it to go. I was legit torn and heartbroken last night. I‚Äôm about to work two jobs now and just get my life together again. Next year I‚Äôm move back to Chicago where I met her before but not for her. For the better future for myself. I‚Äôm gonna have my ups and downs but I will be alright. I‚Äôll improve everything about myself. Going to the gym and just be great. I will see you all next year. Thanks for being so amazing to the ones who left the kind hearted messages for me as I come back and check. Love you all ~ Brian
author: Toasty Bro

text: @Toasty Bro good luck man
author: Fede Des

text: Hey everyone! I‚Äôm back earlier than I expect. So I met this new girl, and it‚Äôs the first time ever I don‚Äôt just wanna have sex with her right from the start. She is just amazing person to spend time with and nothing is forceful at all. I gotta say I believe she‚Äôs gonna be the next one for me. She just balances out my life and fulfills my needs with emotions. It‚Äôs crazy coming back to see how my life as changed over the years and seeing my feelings go up and down. This is why I love YouTube. It‚Äôs a living a breathing community of people from the past to present. Hope everyone is doing well and wish nothing but the best. For you all in your lives. ~ Brian

text: Hey my YouTube peeps. So the girl I was talking with kinda crumble about a month into it. I was wanting a relationship yet she wasn‚Äôt ready for it. I was bent out of shape for awhile but we still talk. Maybe it‚Äôll turn around later on maybe it won‚Äôt. Still, I‚Äôm hitting the gym whenever I‚Äôm not super sore. Got a new car, along with a new job. Sometimes you gotta take your losses for personal gain. Thanks for the returning support guys. I‚Äôll be back in due time üíØ
author: Toasty Bro

text: @Toasty Bro Don't worry dude you'll find the right one for you
author: Gaspard Savoureux

text: Soooo, hey everyone. Back for this huge life update for you all. I had reconnected completely randomly with this girl I had attended middle school with and we hit it off like I didn‚Äôt expect. Not even looking and yet it just fell right into my lap. They say good things will happen when you least expect and yo boy finally found himself a girlfriend. No more just having all these up and down dating emotions going on anymore. For all my followers over these few years that were supportive thank you so much. I won‚Äôt be coming back to this comment and posting for awhile now. It‚Äôll probably become once a year again, though I will revisit to listen to one of my childhoods most iconic songs. Just remember, don‚Äôt go out trying to find someone. Legit just let them find you. Much love guys, and keep pushing to being a better person. See you all soon.
author: Toasty Bro

text:
Happy New Years! Hope you all have been well these past few months. I decided it‚Äôll be easier for me to stay in touch again if I revisit during the start of the year and mid. I‚Äôve been doing extremely well lately for the most part. I‚Äôm still with my amazing girlfriend and going on 4 months almost now. I hope you all have been doing well also and keeping your heads up. I‚Äôve seen a few people asking me to create videos about my life recently not just on this video but a few others. I‚Äôm thinking of starting a twitch channel actually and not just playing games but helping others by talking and counseling you through tough times you may be going through. 
I‚Äôm all about laughing and enjoying life the best you can even during your worst. If anyone is interested feel free to contact me on Twitch at ‚ÄúImToastyBro‚Äù Also feel free to inbox me also if you‚Äôre struggling with depression and such. I‚Äôll do my best to be supportive and turn your negative thoughts into the most positive I can. Hope you all have a blessed and happy holidays!

text: I remember someone suggesting me to do a remix of this song and I refused because I think this song is perfect as it is. I don't think I can bring anything fresh or new to it without ruining it. I don't usually say something like that about a SNES game song as many times the samples are somewhat poor and with powerful VSTis and real instruments you can bring new life to them without deviating from the original sequencing too much. This is an special exception, though. This is, I think, as close as you can get to a perfect-sounding SNES song.

author: FullFledged2010

text:
@FullFledged2010 I am not a fanboy of any console. I own just as many SEGA consoles as Nintendo consoles.

Can you explain to me how 14-bit sound is lower than 9-bit?

SNES games rarely can even run in the same resolution as MD games despite being able to run a higher resolution. Sonic 1, for example, has a higher resolution than Donkey Kong Country.

The controllers have the exact same buttons. Both are stereo and have the same output capability. How is SNES higher here even though it is not?

You are a Nintendo fanboy. SNES is indeed better at colours than MD, just as MD has a better clockspeed. The other factors are minor.

When it comes to SEGA CD, 32X; and other consoles like the Turbo Duo (or TG-CD) and Neo Geo MVS/AES, the SNES it not even close in specs.

I am a retro gamer, not a fanboy, I appreciate every console for what it is good at. On SNES I enjoy the Rare games and Mega Man games. I do not go into a fanboy rage lying about other consoles. On SEGA I like games like Sonic and Streets of Rage.
author: Fox Boy

text: Look up the "full" specs for both systems and behold.. Snes can output a higher resolution than the genesis, has wayy more colors , higher sprite resolution. And as for sound the 16bit dsp in the snes really makes a difference. Thats why genesis sounds a little rougher.
author: FullFledged2010

text:
@FullFledged2010 I just told you it cannot run those resolutions. My computer can probably do 8K, but the games will not run.

Why is Sonic 1 higher resolution than Donkey Kong Country? Reason: SNES cannot run it at that resolution despite being able to run the resolution. High resolution takes resources the system does not have often.

You are clearly ignorant. Go make your own PC, try these things out yourself. You cannot game at any resolution you want without the CPU and RAM to back it up, it is a fact.

I agreed with you on colours. Why are you saying it again?

SNES games sound shallow in comparison to MD. Their bitrate is lower. SEGA CD, like I said, is full 16-bit and can do Q-Sound for surround.

You skipped over most of what I wrote and just posted ignorance. You never answered anything about MD and SNES having the same stereo output, same controller options, and same video/audio capabilities.

And what about the other consoles I listed?

If you do not know or want to lie, stop talking to me. So far SNES is indeed better at colour output and that is it. It is not 'better at everything'.
author: Fox Boy

text:
Satoru Iwata had almost nothing to do with this game, as he wasn't a part of Nintendo before year 2000. Because of the he is not less of a man deserving this honor, although I personally think this song should be devoted to Hiroshi Yamauchi, the head of Nintendo and who had a lot of influence of the game, who passed away in 2013.

I hope they are both in good hands (even though death is final), and I too miss them equally, even if Iwata was not as big for me as Yamauchi.

text: @Mallaceus ‚Äå You are wrong. Iwata was not in a general managing position up until the year 2000, but he actually joined Nintendo in the late 80s-early 90s (I'm not exactly sure of the date) as a part of HAL laboratories, wich he cofounded, and participated as a programmer and later leader of various projects.
author: chcuc

text: I know but he wasn't part of the Nintendo company until 2000 as he was the cofounder of Hal-Laboratories, not Nintendo. Hal worked under Nintendo, however, but just as much as Rare did. They were their own company, but had a contract under Nintendo.

text: +Serfo +Mallaceus I hate how people dedicate EVERY Nintendo game to Iwata even though he had nothing to do with most of them. text:
I was looking at an album of my childhood and scrolling through facebook just now, and I was staring at a picture of me in my room cluttered with dreamcast, ps1, n64, gba, playstation 2, etc games and consoles sitting on my bed in front of one of my 3 small ass tvs playing Donkey Kong Country 2 (My fave game at the time with the 1st) and at the same time I was strolling through facebook newsfeed and someone on my friends list had this song linked and I got a bit teary eyed and ended up here while I'm still looking at that picture.
And just now a thought came to mind. It was at this age when I decided what I wanted to be when I grow up and my dreams are going to come true pretty soon.

text:
@2Gr8te4U I was born in the early 90s. So I grew up in the fifth generation (I was a toddler and ignorant of VGs when the SNES was popular).


First game was Super Mario 64. First DK game was DK64. That game was Rare's BEST!


Had I realized that DKC I, II and III were nearly as awesome, I would've gotten them sooner (for the SNES) rather than downloading through WII U Virtual Console in 2015. When I'm (literally) old enough to drink.


I would've gone out of my way to get the cartridges had the VC price not been so enticing.


And like McCage, I don't sell/throw away consoles, because I KNOW I'll play again at some point.


And it looks like Rare (the REAL Rare, not the shell owned by Microsoft) is coming back with Playtonic's Yooka Laylee!


Cheers! :)

text:
Thank you uploader, for getting the name of this track correct. It is Sticker*BUSH* Symphony, not Sticker*BRUSH*. This misinformation has spread so much that even Google thinks it's the title: "Did you mean stickerbrush?" Spread the word to correct this y'all.



P.s. If you don't believe me, Google image search "Donkey Kong Country 2 soundtrack back cover".¬†Stickerbush is a word that means prickly bush/vine/vegetation. You know, the stuff that's in the level. Stickerbrush is not a word.

author: momsbluedress

text:
The only difference between emulating (2D-games) and playing them on the real console is the quality and the controller. The rest is the exact same.

There are also filters for some emulators that allow for a quality of that of the original console, and controllers and/or adapters that mimic/are the exact same as the original.

Sure, pay the developers, but Rare won't get the money anyways, and Nintendo won't gain anything either if he decides to buy an SNES and play the real thing.

I am an avid videogame collector, I own 2 snes', the complete game DKC 2, and lots of others, but if he wants to play the game, he is allowed to emulate it as he wishes, as it is fully legal to do so. The only illegal part of ROMs are the ones who share them. Owning them and downloading them is nothing short of legal.

text:
Oh the memories...the good memories. Thanks nintendo for giving me so many happy memories as a child. Back then it wasn't about the Shaders, or the graphic engine or your rank in multiplayer online game, it was about the adventure, of fighting against the bad guys to save the princess or get the mighty treasure.

That is what videogames are about, to take you off into a unique adventure, so when you see that final credit roll and then you see it "Game Over" you sigh and smile to yourself saying "I did it..."

Again, thanks Nintendo for making such aweome games back in the day, eventually I became a PC gamer ha ha, but, games like Donkey Kong, Super Mario World, Contra, Mario Kart, Final Fight 1, 2, 3. Street Fighter, Killer Instinct, Yoshi's Island, Zombies ate my neighbours, etc... They'll always have a special place in my heart <3 after all, you just can't beat the classics.

text:
I always felt that the water levels in DKC were easier than some of the ground levels, especially late game.
I find it ironic that this song was originally planned for the scrapped water levels in DKC2. If it was like DKC, it would have been easy, with such serenity. But then it was placed with the Bramble levels, among the most difficult, nerve-wracking levels in the game... and it fit even more perfectly, creating just this amazing feeling of harmonic dissonance between music and gameplay. :3

author: Vincent Rubinetti

text: I don't think that happened here, though. The bit width describes what frequency of sound is currently being played at any given moment in time. Imagine if you were being asked to represent the number 1.1 in terms of 3 decimal points. You'd have to take creative license and say, "Well, I think it's 1.101." It's easier just to report it as "1.100" because that remains true to the source.
author: Yuzu

text:
Well, this is probably 24-bit due to the encoding of the file (which is a standard compromise in audio). But the source is still 16 bit. 

Imagine the music like cars on a highway. 16 cars can drive on a 24 lane highway, but that doesn't mean that that 24 cars are necessarily driving on the highway.  Every lane won't actually be on the highway unless we started out with 24 cars on the highway.

The only way 24 bits will actually be used is by scaling the 16 bit source signal.
author: Yuzu

text: I'm only sixteen years old, but I grew up playing a hand-me-down SNES. I cannot tell you how extremely privileged I feel today to have been able to experience games like this, a piece of the generation that I was supposed to have missed by about a decade. Listening to this OST now, I'm reminded of the fact that although I'm still young, my childhood is already long gone.

text: The word 'epic' has multiple definitions.  When someone uses a word that has multiple meanings, it is the task of the listener to infer from the context which meaning is being used.  One definition of 'epic' is 'an adjective for something exceptionally good and superior.'  On that account this song is very epic.  Granted, 'epic' is a word that is liable to be misused by people who don't know exactly what it means though.
author: Ron Don

text:
1. I'm not being an asshole.
2. Normally I wouldn't care, but the problem is that there isn't really any other word to express the actual meaning of the word "epic"; so when people use it for so many random things the word weakens to the point that we're left with no word to describe a "grand in scale" event.
author: TargetHippo

author: TargetHippo

text:
The definition actually means either pertaining to an epic (as in a poem of a certain length), or something momentously heroic; grand in scale or character.

Nothing about being dramatic in there.  The colossi were very grand in scale, and the amount of courageous and death-defying acts label it as 'epic'.  The word 'dramatic' covers a much broader range of events, though. 'Dramatic' can include "epicry", but it can also include un-epic things.

The more you know!

text: I'm talking about the actual use of the word "epic," which means dramatic. This song is ambient, the furthest thing from that. Shadow of the Colossus is what I would consider epic. They're both great though.

author: jb1980ist

text: After clawing your way through countless brutally difficult levels, you travel to the inevitable apex of DKC 2 level design- a maze of spike covered walls and floors loaded with enemies. You're forced to jump through precariously placed barrels, knowing that one false slip will send you to your death. All the meanwhile, this delicate, soothing music is playing in the background, as if gently pushing you onward. It's a surreal experience, one you're unlikely to experience in any other platformer.

text: I feel as though the nostalgia of these games, especially the music, plays a tremendous role in our lives. I'm 22 years old and I asked for FFIX OST last year and I listen to it almost everyday. Stickerbrush Symphony is on my top 25 most played and why not? I listen to it sometimes before sleep, in my car, even when coming back home from a long night with friends; even they love it and call it 'relaxation, like an Eden.' You can't take away the one thing we all love, and that's VGM. VGM is PLUR.

text:
I love this song.

We had a NES when I was pretty little. Before I could play video games, I sat and watched my older brother play Donkey Kong Country 2. This song always stood out clearer in my mind than all the others from the game. When I hear the first beginning notes now, I can't help but stop and smile. Our NES is gone, and so is Donkey Kong Country 2. But this song--and DK2--will always be a memorable part of my childhood.

text: (2/2) and let's not forget what video game music sounded like in 1994-1996! Play some other games from that era and be amazed at how flat they sound. This is a piece that strangely fits the levels its played over, but does for sure. The new version is obv. much less focused on atmosphere since it's being played over a combat game. author: Eddie Richard

text:
(1/2) And actually LyfSukz, just to anticipate what your next comment will be, I read your comment on the Brawl's version page about how there's four "themes" to the song.

I don't even completely agree about those segments sounding like each of the themes you suggested, but no matter what, it's still about the sound. The raw audio. A song can have good themes and still sound harsh on the ears. The atmosphere the DKC2s version opens up on is simply undeniable. It's bleek and brooding,
author: Eddie Richard

text:
@LyfSukz You would be stunned to know how "honest"ly I listen to music. I give nearly everything a chance. Brawl's Stickerbrush removes the eerie gloom that the original has and makes it upbeat and poppy. As far as I've seen, I'm not the only retro fan who feels this way.

If I were to rephrase what I wrote so it sounds like bitter: Given the chance to listen to the original or the remix, I would pick the original 100% of the time.

text:
This song sums up the entire game, how it was a great game, and how it was made great... How each level was interesting and fun to get through, and then the feeling of accomplishment you'd get when you finish a fairly difficult level.. Or when you lose your last life and the last time you saved was six levels ago...

Simply put, the surreal atmosphere this song portrays is enough to bring back memories of one of the best games on the SNES.

text:
NO! REALLY?!

Let me put emphasis on the following part of my previous statement: "INSTEAD. OF. THE. OTHER. WAY. AROUND."

Look at studios such as Valve and Epic Games, one of their shared design philosophies are to make the map first, ensure it's playable, THEN put textures and art assets into it.

All of Rare's games have suffered from hideous design, and it's exactly because they disregard this school of design.

text:
Personally I wonder if motion controlls will ever catch on.

Natal and the Sony motion-thingy have already proven that good motion sensor technology already exists, but I wonder, how does it improve gameplay?

It doesn't give you any sense of virtual reality, because there is no physical feedback. Hitting a ball in Wii Tennis is not like hitting an actual ball, all you're doing is simulating the movement that accompanies it.

What motioncontrols do is replace physical joystick with a virtual one

text: Except music lacks the well-defined win condition of a sport.  Forgive me if I was unclear, but I meant that declaring a musical winner in this fashion was fruitless, not that there could never be winners in anything.
author: Melancholia

text:
Fine. Let us not declare a winner.

When there are races, there are no winners. There is just a person who ran faster than the other person. Everyone in that race worked so hard to compete, but no one wins. We will take away the medals that first, second, and third place get, just because no one wins.

Music contains just as much passion as any sport. Composers place their time, effort, and essence into making music. That's why this list is here. We celebrate the greatest.

This is the greatest.
author: NewestOneAtTime

text: We're not their target audience, which is tragic because they have no drive to reach the quality they once had.  Though I think within Nintendo you'll find a fair number of men and women (mostly men, sadly) that grew up with an NES or SNES and still want to make great games, regardless of what their bosses plan.
author: Melancholia

text:
Declaring a winner is ever fruitless.  As much as I love this song, I know that the contest will never end.

Also, you forgot the Metroid series.
author: Melancholia

text:
You'll see people debating over which VGM is the best. The common names that come up are the Mega Man series, the Chrono series, the Zelda series, maybe the Mario series, the Final Fantasy series, Secret of Mana series, 
and the Donkey Kong series. 

But after you listen to this song, you feel at peace with yourself. There is no battle for best VGM. There is only this song. Let us drift off into the forest, watching the beautiful sunset in the horizon.

In short, this song has no rivals.

author: Samsquamch23

text: the music here is more beautiful than the stuff they composed for their animal platformers on the N64 (with probably only Rock Solid and Conker the King Reprise from Conker's Bad Fur Day coming close to the style and maybe the Fungi Forest (and possibly Fungus Forest's lost track) not that they made bad music I just find that their earlier stuff sounded great, and for a soundtrack like this to rival some of even the best RPG's music really says something about the earlier work.
author: The #1 Yoshi

text: as well as the two final Gruntilda boss music for Kazooie and Tooie, and I'll always sing and listen to Sloprano after hearing it not too long ago, but try comparing Rare's style of music (at least for their animal platformers) that they composed on the N64 to their music like here in DKC2 and you'll noticed they changed their style of doing things, also they gave a more cartoony sound to their music for those kind of games but I don't mind that however the music here is more beautiful *2bcont.*
author: The #1 Yoshi

text: only with a different tune over that made it feel like they were music that were looping in more than one way, though Rock Solid is awesome and original and I liked Conker the King (and have a great liking for the reprise version at the end ev en if the track is a ripoff from Clockwork Orange) and I'll always love Banjo-Tooie's Atlantis theme (which was one of the few worlds to actually do a drastic music change as you went from the town into the lagoon) as well as the two *2bcont.*
author: The #1 Yoshi

text: but the SNES games (well I'm only aware of Donkey Kong Country and some of Donkey Kong Country 2's tracks (but I still do say they are amazing and every time I listen to its stuff I'm more eager to get to the first stage that will feature it) the SNES games seem more like they were worked on more sure I see they reuse them for some levels but most of the Cartoony Platformers for their N64 music just used the same music only with a different tune in the same world over agin *2bcont.*
author: The #1 Yoshi

text: I find these interesting, My first exposure to Rare and Nintendo's greatness was Banjo-Kazooie though hearing these tracks makes Me wonder if they got a little lazy with music for their animal cartoony platrformers when they hit the N64, sure I love the tracks from a lot of their N64 games, I have good memories of Diddy Kong Racing, Banjo-Kazooie and Banjo-Tooie's soundtracks and I love their good humor with Conker's Bad Fur Day's Sloprano track but the SNES *2bcont.*
author: The #1 Yoshi

text: Exactly I beileve the music for the types of stages it was on is what saved many peoples T.V. screens from having controllers thrown at them during those hardest parts, some people say it shouldn't be on such a hard stage but I beileve theres a reason its on those stages, because without this little calm piece it would have nothing but endless frustration and nothing to possibly stop the rage and we already know theres enough hard stuff in games that have nothing to get rid of the rage already.
author: The #1 Yoshi

text: This is exactly what was going on in my mind while trying to do the Squawks part of Animal Antics. "Oh my god this is so frustrating, but this music, I can't help but feel happy."

text:
I LOVED Bramble Blast. The barrel blast course was awesome, and it gave you a chance to really enjoy the music and the scenery (which was also incredible).

I HATED Bramble Scramble. They changed the bright blue skies and vivid green brambles to this washed-out, dreary look, and you spent half the level trying not to fly into the brambles as Squawks, while avoiding those goddamn red Zingers. The music was the only thing that made it bearable.

text:
Since both of my prior comments were -6'd below the viewing threshold, I'll try to make my statements a little more clear.

Stickerbrush Symphony is not only one of the best video game songs ever, but one of the best melodies ever, period. I'll reuse the words I used in my last comment: bleak and somber. And a new one: mystifying. 

I DEEPLY respect Nintendo for at least looking into their golden past and reviving this song for Brawl, but they completely stripped it of its essence. Thats just it

text: Many hot afternoons and sleepless nights were spent playing this game: finding those elusive Krem Coins and DK Coins, making sure that all level names had a ! and a DK Logo next to them. text:
That's one of my favorite songs ever! I loved the DKC series when I was a kid. I first played DKC1 then DKC2. However, I never had the chance to really play DKC3 until years later. I remember trying the first level at an old friend's place. I first really played DKC3 when I bought the GBA version.

I loved the series so much that I also bought DKC1 and DKC2 on the GBA (I also have the GBC versions). I prefer DKC2 but that's because of nostalgia.

I'm also happy they remixed it for SSBB!
